hints_html:
Just do it.

Alternatively, you could evaluate the last two terms easily and then use a trig substitution on the first integral.

Following hint 2, you can use \(x = \sin\theta\)
hints_latex:
Alternatively, you could evaluate the last two terms easily and then use
a trig substitution on the first integral.
hints_raw:
Just do it.
Alternatively, you could evaluate the last two terms easily and then use a trig substitution on the first integral.
Following hint 2, you can use <math> x = \sin\theta </math>
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
\(\int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} + 1 - x^{2}\right)\, dx = \arcsin(x) + x - \frac{x^{3}}{3} + C\)

We still have

\(\int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} + 1 - x^{2}\right)\, dx = \int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} \right) \, dx+ x - \frac{x^{3}}{3}\)

To evaluate the last integral, let \(x = \sin\theta\) so that \(dx = \cos\theta d\theta\) and thus, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} \right) \, dx &= \int \left(\frac{\cos\theta}{\sqrt{1-\sin^{2}\theta}} \right) \, d \theta\\ &= \int \left(\frac{\cos\theta}{\cos\theta} \right) \, d \theta\\ &= \int \, d \theta \\ &= \theta + C\\ &= \arcsin(x) + C\end{aligned}\]

and so

\(\int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} + 1 - x^{2}\right)\, dx = \arcsin(x) + x - \frac{x^{3}}{3} + C\)
sols_latex:
We still have

$\int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} + 1 - x^{2}\right)\, dx = \int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} \right) \, dx+ x - \frac{x^{3}}{3}$

To evaluate the last integral, let $x = \sin\theta$ so that
$dx = \cos\theta d\theta$ and thus, we have

\begin{align*}
\int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} \right) \, dx &= \int \left(\frac{\cos\theta}{\sqrt{1-\sin^{2}\theta}} \right) \, d \theta\\
&= \int \left(\frac{\cos\theta}{\cos\theta} \right) \, d \theta\\
&= \int  \, d \theta \\
&=  \theta + C\\
&= \arcsin(x) + C
\end{align*}

and so

$\int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} + 1 - x^{2}\right)\, dx = \arcsin(x) + x - \frac{x^{3}}{3} + C$
sols_raw:
<math>
\int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} + 1 - x^{2}\right)\, dx = \arcsin(x) + x - \frac{x^{3}}{3} + C
</math>
We still have

<math>
\int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} + 1 - x^{2}\right)\, dx = \int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} \right) \, dx+ x - \frac{x^{3}}{3} 
</math>

To evaluate the last integral, let <math> x = \sin\theta </math> so that <math> dx = \cos\theta d\theta </math> and thus, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
\int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} \right) \, dx &= \int \left(\frac{\cos\theta}{\sqrt{1-\sin^{2}\theta}} \right) \, d \theta\\
&= \int \left(\frac{\cos\theta}{\cos\theta} \right) \, d \theta\\
&= \int  \, d \theta \\
&=  \theta + C\\
&= \arcsin(x) + C
\end{align}
</math>

and so 

<math>
\int \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x^{2}}} + 1 - x^{2}\right)\, dx = \arcsin(x) + x - \frac{x^{3}}{3} + C
</math>
